Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I stared at my laptop, the calendar reminders flashing insistently. In ten minutes, our team’s final meeting before the project launch would begin. My manager had emphasized how crucial everyone’s input was—this was the last chance to raise concerns or suggest changes. As a colleague, I knew my absence would be noticed, maybe even resented. But at the same time, my phone buzzed with a notification: the live online forum for our district’s candidates was starting. As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to listen, to ask questions, to help shape the future of my community. I’d always believed in being an active participant, not just a bystander. The two windows glared at me from my screen, each demanding my attention, each representing a part of who I am. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—my team counting on me, my community needing my voice. I felt torn, anxious, and guilty, knowing that whichever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
